I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  cluster  will  support  the 
implementation of the Climate Change Operational Framework 2017–2030 (CCOF2030) of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), which defines how ADB can facilitate a regional shift onto a 
development path that is climate-resilient and low in greenhouse gas emissions, in line with the 
Paris Agreement, the Sustainable Development Goals, and the Sendai Framework for Disaster 
Risk Reduction.1 The TA cluster will help boost the capacity of developing member countries 
(DMCs) for meeting their climate objectives by (i) assisting in refining and translating nationally 
determined contributions (NDCs) into climate investment plans, which may be implemented with 
ADB assistance; (ii) improving DMCs' access to external public and private climate finance, 
including  support  for  innovative  financing  mechanisms;  and  (iii)  developing  methods  and 
approaches to establish baselines and monitoring tools for indicators to measure and gauge DMC 
progress on climate actions and ADB’s contribution to these actions. 
 
2.  The TA cluster is strongly aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030, particularly the operational 
priority  of tackling  climate change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing 
environmental sustainability.2 It is included in the 2018–2019 Climate Change and Disaster Risk 
Management Thematic Group work plan.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The achievement of the Paris Agreement depends on the implementation of progressively 
more ambitious climate actions, including those described in DMC NDCs.4 However, NDCs in 
their current form are insufficient to meet the 2C target.5 Given the lack of public financial 
resources,  weak  financial  and  institutional  systems,  and  limited  climate  knowledge  and 
awareness,  external  support  in  the  form  of  finance,  technology,  knowledge,  and  capacity 
development is needed to implement the current NDCs, and to design and implement more 
ambitious NDCs. 
 
4.  Significant  investments in  low-carbon  and  climate-resilient  infrastructure  are  needed 
across developing Asia, where ADB assessed the infrastructure gap to total $26.2 trillion, or

4  NDCs outline countries’ commitments to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and their climate adaptation priorities. As of 
September 2018, 38 of 40 DMCs receiving ADB financing support have ratified the Paris Agreement. The Kyrgyz Republic 
and Uzbekistan are the remaining DMCs that have not ratified the Paris Agreement. 
5  Climate Action Tracker. The Climate Action Tracker estimates that the planned contribution in most NDCs is not in line with

2 
$1.7 trillion annually, during 2016–2030.6 To mobilize the needed investment, DMC governments 
must devise climate investment plans and develop climate projects that help mobilize financing 
from various sources, particularly the private sector. However, most NDCs do not match climate 
actions with concrete financing mechanisms, including green bonds, project bonds, climate risk 
insurance, or guarantee facilities. Consequently, opportunities to mobilize financing are not fully 
pursued,  and  the  resulting  lack  in  resources  hampers  climate  action  and  undermines  the 
achievement of NDC objectives. 
 
5.  Transparency and accountability are also key factors in the successful delivery of the Paris 
Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals. Results-based monitoring and evaluation is 
a powerful tool for ensuring transparency and accountability on finance flows and climate actions. 
Establishing reliable monitoring systems and enabling the measurement of progress will be useful 
for DMCs to effectively monitor the achievement of their climate and development goals, and also 
help ADB measure progress toward the CCOF2030 and Strategy 2030 climate finance objectives 
and their contributions to climate and development outcomes in DMCs. 
 
6.  The CCOF2030 underscores ADB’s commitment to helping its DMCs meet their climate 
commitments, including by supporting the implementation of their NDCs and facilitating access to 
public, private, domestic, and international climate finance. In November 2017, ADB formally 
joined the NDC Partnership, an international grouping of countries, development agencies, and 
international financial institutions that coordinates support for developing countries to gain access 
to financial, technology-related, knowledge, and capacity development assistance to achieve 
ambitious climate goals while enhancing sustainable development.7 ADB supports DMCs in the 
pursuit  of  their  climate  and  development  objectives  by  providing  TA,  facilitating  innovative 
financing, disseminating knowledge, developing capacity, and building partnerships. 
 
7.  The  TA  cluster  will  contribute  to  ADB’s  support  for  DMCs  in  implementing  NDCs, 
mobilizing finance, and monitoring and tracking climate actions and financial flows in line with the 
Paris Agreement. DMCs have articulated the need for such support during the DMC consultation 
on the CCOF2030 and increasingly through DMC requests via the NDC Partnership (e.g., from 
the Marshall Islands, Mongolia, the Philippines, and Viet Nam).8 Responding to this will enable 
ADB to identify and meet climate financing and capacity development needs in DMCs. This will 
help achieve the Strategy 2030 target of 75% of ADB’s operations being climate relevant by 2030, 
and ADB’s own climate investment reaching $80 billion cumulatively during 2019–2030.9 
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
8.  By collectively supporting the CCOF2030 implementation, the proposed subprojects are 
strategically linked to a common overall objective of enhancing the capacity of DMCs for climate 
action implementation. In contrast to a stand-alone TA, the TA cluster modality allows for flexibility 
in expanding outputs and integrating any future initiatives to support CCOF2030 implementation. 
 
                                                
6  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia’s Infrastructure Needs. Manila. 
7  NDC Partnership. Hosted by the World Resources Institute and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate 
Change, the NDC Partnership is a global coalition of countries and institutions working to mobilize support and achieve 
ambitious climate goals while enhancing sustainable development. It is co-chaired by the governments of Germany and 
Morocco. 
8  ADB held a regional consultation workshop on the CCOF2030 on 6–7 March 2017 at the ADB headquarters. 
9  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
9.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impact: low-carbon development and climate 
resilience in Asia and the Pacific enhanced.10 The TA cluster will have the following outcome: 
capacity of selected DMCs for implementing climate actions enhanced.11 
 
10.  Output 1: Implementation of NDCs in selected DMCs supported. The TA cluster will 
assist DMCs in developing and implementing their NDCs. It will support (i) regional, national, 
sector, or subsector assessments of the needs and concrete opportunities for sovereign and 
nonsovereign climate investment, in line with NDC priorities; (ii) the development of climate 
investment plans for selected sectors or subsectors that outline how NDC objectives may be 
achieved by mobilizing finance from appropriate sources and mechanisms, implementing a 
supportive policy and institutional framework, and developing adequate knowledge and capacity; 
and (iii) the identification and development of climate change priority project preconcepts for 
implementation through ADB sovereign and/or nonsovereign assistance. The TA cluster will help 
DMC governments carry out effective outreach and engagement with domestic and international 
finance providers and other stakeholders to facilitate a scaled-up climate investment for the 
realization of NDC objectives. It will further build DMC capacity for NDC-related investments, and 
support the conduct of national and regional consultations and training workshops on climate 
change risk management and investments. Selected reports will be published as knowledge 
products, with limited print copies disseminated to stakeholders from DMCs and development 
partners. Activities under output 1 will be closely coordinated with regional departments. 
 
11.  Output 2: Financial mechanisms to develop the climate actions of DMCs enhanced. 
The TA cluster will deliver a review of ADB climate finance projects to gather examples of best 
practices from the public and the private sectors, including an analysis of vehicles to catalyze 
private capital, such as direct project finance (lending, guarantees, syndications, and equity 
investments);  blended  finance;12  and  public–private  partnerships13  or  special  investment 
vehicles.14 It will develop an appraisal methodology to support regional departments in identifying 
relevant climate finance sources or funds for DMCs in Asia and the Pacific, complete with a 
classification of fund terms and conditions and with criteria to review the NDCs (mitigation, 
adaptation,  and  disaster  and  risk  management)  for  their  climate  finance  potential  (identify 
innovative approaches across sectors, themes, and regions and define priority countries and 
sectors for operational support).15 It will also provide an analysis of enabling environments in 
selected priority DMCs to develop (i) public and/or private incentives for climate investments,

which will lower the financial costs of such ventures; (ii) uniform standards on registration 
conditions and impact monitoring of such investments; and (iii) mechanisms to improve access to 
climate finance. Output 2 will build on the work carried out under output 1 and will integrate an 
analysis of regional infrastructure investment strategies and hurdles to transboundary climate 
finance. The deliverables under output 2 will be published in digital and print format. Capacity 
building workshops and knowledge events will be organized to disseminate output 2 findings. 
 
12.  Output 3: Mechanisms to measure, monitor, and report on commitments made 
under the Paris Agreement established. The TA cluster will establish baselines and targets to 
support the monitoring of DMCs' progress toward meeting their NDC commitments, as well as 
ADB’s contribution to the NDC objectives. It will determine methodological issues and solutions 
to measure, monitor, and report on progress toward the climate and development goals. Under 
output 3, the TA cluster will (i) develop results framework indicators for selected DMCs in line with 
NDC commitments; (ii) consult with selected DMCs on the links between the CCOF2030 results 
framework indicators and the NDC implementation priorities; (iii) work with ADB’s operations and 
other departments to develop approaches for monitoring relevant CCOF2030 results framework 
indicators; and (iv) establish baseline and associated indicators under the CCOF2030, including 
related monitoring tools and systems. Knowledge products and services from this output will 
provide overall guidance and tools to monitor the results framework of DMCs and ADB. Selected 
products will be published in digital format, with limited print copies. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $4,550,000, of which (i) $750,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), (ii) $800,000 
will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6), and 
(iii) $3,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.16 Detailed cost 
estimates  and  financing  arrangements  will  be  presented  in  each  TA  subproject  proposal 
submitted for approval. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA cluster. The Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management 
Division of its Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will lead the overall 
implementation of the subprojects. Target DMC selection, activities, and consultant outputs under 
each subproject will be closely coordinated with operations departments, resident missions, and 
sector and thematic groups. The Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Division will 
select, administer, and evaluate consultants. Each TA subproject proposal will be submitted for 
approval  by  the  director  general  of  the  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change 
Department, following the business process for processing knowledge and support TA clusters.17  
Subproject activities will start only after approval.

national consulting inputs. About 110 person-months of international inputs (e.g., climate finance

Supporting the Implementation of ADB’s Climate Change Operational Framework 2017–2030, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Source: Asian Development Bank.

Appendix 2  9 
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Supporting Ambitious Climate Action through the 
Subproject 1  Implementation of DMCs’ NDCs 
Indicative outputs and activities  Linked to TA cluster output 1, subproject 1 comprises outputs 
and activities focused on supporting the development and 
implementation of NDCs that outline mitigation commitments and 
adaptation priorities of DMCs under the Paris Agreement.a 
 
The outputs to be delivered under subproject 1 will include 
(i) regional, national, sector, or subsector assessments that will 
identify the needs and concrete opportunities for sovereign and 
nonsovereign climate investments in DMCs in line with NDC 
priorities; (ii) climate investment plans for selected sectors or 
subsectors that will be developed based on the analysis of DMC 
NDCs; (iii) preconcepts on priority climate change mitigation and 
adaptation projects for implementation through ADB sovereign 
and/or nonsovereign assistance; and (iv) enhancement of 
knowledge and skills of DMC representatives, including women, 
on climate change risk management and investments, of 
ministries in DMCs. These outputs will be in line with the 
development of CPSs and COBPs and will also be guided by 
operational processes and country dialogue efforts in 
coordination with operational departments. 
 
Country assessments will include assessments of in-country 
enabling environments, technologies, gaps, and opportunities for 
climate financing. Preconcepts will be developed for priority 
climate change mitigation and adaptation projects in the sectors 
or subsectors covered by the supported climate investment 
plans, to serve not only as investment opportunities for ADB but 
also as a proof of concept on how NDC priorities may be linked 
to financing. Sectors that may be covered include agriculture and 
natural resources, energy, transport, urban development, and 
water. Preconcepts will likely include information on needed 
investment; potential cofinancing sources; climate mitigation 
and/or adaptation impact; relevance to DMC development and 
climate plans, including their NDCs; non-climate co-benefits; and 
required policy, technology, and capacity building support for 
project implementation. 
 
Subproject 1 outputs will be guided by related documents of the 
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and 
corresponding assessments undertaken. It will build on the 
experience of past and ongoing TA projects, e.g., a TA project 
that successfully promoted climate technology investment 
planning through the assessments undertaken and contributed to 
ADB’s CPS development and investment planning.b 
 
Subproject 1 will be implemented in four or five DMCs. The 
selection of DMCs will be determined in close coordination with 
regional departments. Priority will be given to DMCs where the 
CPS and/or COBP process will be initiated or where gaps exist 
and opportunities for NDC support can be maximized. 
Subproject 1 will also ideally aim to cover at least one DMC per 
region, and DMCs with differing circumstances and NDC

10  Appendix 2 
development. Coverage for additional DMCs or additional 
activities will be subject to additional external cofinancing 
support. Subproject 1 will also inform, and benefit from, the 
findings and outputs of subproject 2, e.g., innovative finance 
vehicles. ADB’s membership of the NDC Partnership will help 
ensure a coordinated approach with other development partners 
in supporting the implementation of NDCs. 
 
Consultants will be engaged to support the conduct of 
subproject 1 activities and delivery of outputs. Subproject 1 
activities will include (i) developing selection criteria for the 
prioritization of DMCs and identification of targeted DMCs, 
(ii) conducting country assessments and consultations, 
(iii) holding national and regional consultations with governments 
and stakeholders to present assessment results and the 
developed climate investment plans, and (iv) conducting training 
and/or workshops for climate-relevant government agencies on 
climate change risk management and investments. Training, 
consultations, and workshops will be monitored for effectiveness 
and/or inclusiveness. 
 
Selected reports will be published as knowledge products in 
English and the local language, as needed, with limited print 
copies disseminated to training and/or workshop participants 
from DMCs and development partners, including through the 
NDC Partnership. 
 
Indicative implementation  ADB, through the Climate Change and Disaster Risk 
arrangements  Management Division under the Thematic Advisory Service 
Cluster of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department, will be the implementing agency. Subproject 1 will 
be implemented in close coordination with operations 
departments, including resident missions, and relevant sector 
and thematic groups (i.e., ESG, RDFS TG, TSG, USG, and 
WSG) to communicate on activities, including engagement of 
consultants, and selected outputs. 
 
Implementation schedule  Subproject 1 is expected to be implemented from December 
2018 to November 2023. 
 
Enhancing Financial Mechanisms to Develop the Climate 
Subproject 2  Actions of DMCs 
Indicative outputs and activities  Linked to TA cluster output 2, subproject 2 will expand the TA 
cluster activities in selected DMCs, with a focus on analyzing 
financial mechanisms supporting climate actions. Subproject 2 
will enable the review of innovative financial instruments that can 
leverage ADB’s own resources to attract climate finance and will 
assist DMCs in building enabling environments to catalyze 
climate investments. It will also provide a review of ADB projects 
that have promoted innovative financing modalities and develop 
common, cross-sector approaches and best practices to identify 
the appropriate vehicles and strategies for attracting resources 
from the private sector. Subproject 2 will also integrate the 
drivers of regional climate and infrastructure investment 
strategies, notably in the CAREC subregion and in the GMS.

Appendix 2  11 
The outputs to be delivered under subproject 2 will include (i) a 
scoping paper on ADB best practice for climate finance 
mobilization; (ii) an appraisal of methodologies to support 
regional departments in the identification of relevant climate 
finance vehicles; (iii) innovative blended finance vehicles for 
priority sectors; (iv) comprehensive sources of climate finance; 
and (v) assessments on enabling environments and 
transboundary climate investments. 
 
Subproject 2 will be undertaken in four to six DMCs in at least 
two ADB regional departments. Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (TASF-6) resources will be applied to conduct analyses in 
DMCs that receive funding from the Asian Development Fund, 
particularly DMCs where synergies can be identified with other 
components of the TA cluster and with stand-alone TA projects 
that support the CCOF2030 implementation. These DMCs 
include Bhutan, Cambodia, the Kyrgyz Republic, Myanmar, 
Nepal, Tajikistan, and Tonga. 
 
The selection of DMCs will be determined in close coordination 
with regional departments and PSOD. Coverage for additional 
DMCs or additional activities in DMCs will be subject to additional 
external cofinancing support. 
 
Consultants will be engaged to support the conduct of 
subproject 2 activities and delivery of outputs. Subproject 2 
activities will primarily cover the (i) identification of priority DMCs 
for assistance, (ii) conduct of scoping and/or appraisal on climate 
finance in the selected DMCs, and (iii) conduct of workshops for 
the dissemination of results. 
 
The deliverables to be published in digital and print format under 
output 2 will include best practices under subcomponent 1, 
appraisal methodology (practical guide) under subcomponent 2, 
and a working paper for the analysis undertaken in 
subcomponent 3. The audience for subcomponents 1 and 2 will 
be ADB DMCs and staff; the print format is limited to 100 copies 
each. For subcomponent 3, the audience will include ADB 
DMCs, ADB staff, and the general public. About 300 copies will 
be printed and four workshops will be organized to disseminate 
results in the selected DMCs in consultation with the regional 
departments. 
 
Indicative implementation  ADB, through the Climate Change and Disaster Risk 
arrangements  Management Division under the Thematic Advisory Service 
Cluster of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department, will be the implementing agency. Subproject 2 will 
be implemented in close coordination with operations 
departments and the FSG. 
 
Implementation schedule  Subproject 2 is expected to be implemented from April 2019 to 
March 2022. 
 
Establishing Mechanisms to Measure, Monitor, and Report 
Subproject 3  on Commitments Made Under the Paris Agreement

12  Appendix 2 
Indicative outputs and activities  Linked to TA cluster output 3, subproject 3 will deepen TA cluster 
activities in selected DMCs. It will focus on developing results 
framework indicators in line with NDC commitments and the 
CCOF2030. 
 
Subproject 3 will be undertaken in at least two DMCs, guided by 
the country selection of subproject 1. The outputs will be 
delivered at the DMC level, in the context of monitoring NDC 
commitments; and at the ADB level, in relation to the CCOF2030 
implementation. The outputs will include (i) stronger capacity of 
DMC representatives for monitoring the results framework and 
related NDC indicators; and (ii) an enhanced knowledge base on 
results measurement, monitoring, and reporting, including the 
development of approach papers and country guidance notes 
and the establishment of a related database. 
 
Country-specific results framework indicators are expected to 
cover focus areas of commitments made by the DMCs, mostly in 
energy and transport. Performance indicators will include 
finance, technology, emissions reductions, and land use. This 
subproject will also make use of subproject 2 outputs in relation 
to financial instruments and enabling environments that lead to 
climate finance investments. 
 
The activities will be done in close consultation with country 
stakeholders and relevant climate agencies from select DMCs. 
 
At the ADB level, results framework indicators will be developed 
in the context of the CCOF2030’s monitoring and reporting 
mechanism, which will include refining its performance indicators 
and determining baselines and targets for these indicators. Some 
indicators cover performance on climate change mitigation 
(greenhouse gas emission reductions, renewable energy 
capacity, and the like); climate change adaptation; climate 
finance; and climate and disaster resilience. The subproject will 
also consider the best approach or tool to measure these 
indicators, both in the interim, during a stocktaking exercise of 
outputs and achievements in 2023, and the final assessment by 
2030. 
 
Consultants will be engaged to support the conduct of 
subproject 3 activities and delivery of outputs. Subproject 3 
activities will include the (i) conduct of consultation workshops 
with DMCs; (ii) development of country papers and guidelines in 
English and in the local language, as needed; (iii) development of 
a results database; and (iv) conduct of workshops and training 
for DMCs. 
 
Indicative implementation  ADB, through the Climate Change and Disaster Risk 
arrangements  Management Division under the Thematic Advisory Service 
Cluster of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department, will be the implementing agency. Subproject 3 will 
be implemented in close coordination with operations 
departments, SPD, and sector and thematic groups.

Appendix 2  13 
Implementation schedule  Subproject 3 is expected to be implemented from April 2019 to 
March 2021.

Climate Change Operational Framework 2017–2030; COBP = country operations business plan; CPS = country 
partnership strategy; DMC = developing member country; ESG = Energy Sector Group; FSG = Finance Sector Group;
